admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
subsc: General public administration sector,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Land Titling III
            Project for Thailand was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that following up
            sector work, targets and implementation plans are better
            conceived. However, when components involve coordination
            between multiple agencies, new technologies or changing
            roles of public institutions increase the difficulty of well
            thought-out plans. Demarcation of forest boundaries suffered
            considerable delays and its achievement was much lower than
            the planned targets due to lack of working arrangements,
            policy direction, and coordination between Department of
            Lands, Land Development Department, and Royal Forestry
            Department. Introduction of new technologies should be
            phased and tested at a smaller-scale before expansion.
            Property valuation development programs should clearly
            identify the respective roles of the public and private
            sector in valuation, and the most appropriate
            institution/agency for support to valuation development. A
            strong commitment of the borrower/implementing agencies is a
            prerequisite for successful implementation. Bold
            initiatives, such as this 20-year program to provide land
            titles, create spill-over effects and valuable public-sector competency.
